results.headline: She Came to Do Good and Stayed to Do Well
results.summary_short: In “Khoobsurat,” a daffy physical therapist charms an aristocratic family.

results.headline: A Life-Size Labyrinth Is the Bane of These Boys
results.summary_short: “The Maze Runner,” a young-adult dystopian story, finds a platoon of boys lost in a strange setting.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Maze Runner

results.headline: Bible Belt Soul Search
results.summary_short: Roberto Minervini’s “Stop the Pounding Heart” is the story of a young Texas girl in a strict Christian home who finds herself attracted to a rodeo rider.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stop the Pounding Heart

results.headline: Cannibalistic Gerbils and a Cryogenic Mother-in-Law
results.summary_short: “Space Station 76,” a science-fiction-drama parody, stars Liv Tyler and Patrick Wilson.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Space Station 76

results.headline: Looking to Adopt, but Finding Trouble
results.summary_short: In “Reclaim,” an American couple trying to adopt a Haitian girl find themselves ensnared by a trafficking and kidnapping ring.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reclaim

results.headline: Fill ’er Up, but Hold the Gas
results.summary_short: “Pump” chronicles the history of dependence on oil and features a biofuels success story in Brazil.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pump

results.headline: I’d Walk 1,700 Miles With a Camel
results.summary_short: “Tracks” is based on Robyn Davidson’s memoir about her 1,700-mile walk across the Australian desert in 1977, accompanied only by four camels, a dog and the occasional National Geographic photographer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tracks

results.headline: Beware the Old Sailor Bearing Tea
results.summary_short: Directed by Kevin Smith, “Tusk” is a weird, even goofy, hybrid of kidnap drama and Frankensteinian horror.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tusk

results.headline: The Nurse, the Musician and the Video Artist
results.summary_short: In “Swim Little Fish Swim,” a couple with a small child and little else in common are changed when a young Frenchwoman comes into their lives.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Swim Little Fish Swim

results.headline: Never Prejudge a Pack Rat
results.summary_short: In “Life’s a Breeze,” helpful offspring clean out their mother’s home, unwittingly jettisoning her life savings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life's a Breeze

results.headline: Out of the Freezer and Into the Fight Ring
results.summary_short: “Iceman,” directed by Law Wing-cheong, centers on a Ming dynasty warrior who encounters old foes when he is revived after a centuries-long deep freeze.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Iceman

results.headline: Angsty Reunion of Callow Collegians
results.summary_short: The romantic comedy “Hollidaysburg” centers on recent high school graduates who reunite around Thanksgiving in their hometown.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hollidaysburg

results.headline: A Down Yankees Fan Gets a Pinstripes Pick Me Up
results.summary_short: “Henry & Me” is an animated film about a cancer-stricken boy who’s transported to a dreamlike place where Yankees greats play on.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Henry & Me

results.display_title: Hector and the Search for Happiness
results.headline: If You’re Unhappy and You Know It
results.summary_short: “Hector and the Search for Happiness,” is based on a novel by the psychiatrist François Lelord.

results.display_title: This is Where I Leave You
results.headline: Pallbearers Par Excellence
results.summary_short: “This Is Where I Leave You” stars Jason Bateman as a man who loses his marriage and job and then must gather with his family to mourn for his father.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This is Where I Leave You

results.headline: At Home in War. In War at Home.
results.summary_short: In “Fort Bliss,” Michelle Monaghan finds rough going returning to her family after a tour in Afghanistan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fort Bliss

results.headline: Work, Love and Therapy, in So Many Bytes
results.summary_short: Christoph Waltz plays a hapless laborer in Terry Gilliam’s latest fanciful foray into a dystopian future, which revisits some of the themes in the director’s “Brazil.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Zero Theorem

results.headline: They Know Martial and Other Arts
results.summary_short: In “Brush With Danger,” the siblings Livi Zheng and Ken Zheng play sibling immigrants trying to make it in America through paintings and martial arts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brush With Danger

results.headline: Good vs. Evil, Both Bloody
results.summary_short: In “A Walk Among the Tombstones” the private investigator Matthew Scudder, from the Lawrence Block novels, pursues a case that leads him to an underworld of brutality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Walk Among the Tombstones

results.headline: For This Con Artist, No Crime That Pays
results.summary_short: “Art and Craft” looks at Mark A. Landis, who liked donating faked paintings to American museums, and the museum official determined to expose him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Art and Craft
